--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "aimike002" <aimike002@...> wrote:
>
> 1) As I=
 understand it, (fully connected) NEAT starts out with 
> just one bias nod=
e -  is that right?

NEAT only ever uses one bias node.  There's no point i=
n having more 
than one.

> 2) Would there be any advantage in adding a fea=
ture where NEAT
> could mutate node types from hidden to bias - i.e. to inc=
rease the
>  overall chances of more links from bias nodes being created ?
=

I don't know, but I doubt, you'd find any advantage in evolving node 
type=
s in that manner.  It seems destructive to the network.

If you'd like to i=
ncrease the chance of more links from the bias 
node, then you can simply d=
o that in your mutation code.

> 3)Lastly, (there may be no right answer to=
 this one, but if there 
is a
> convention in NEAT I would like to follow i=
t) If I start with an
> initial  population of genomes, each fully connecte=
d to the outputs,
> then perturb the weights, before dong any crosssover/mu=
tations - is
> that population at that stage referred to as generation zero=
 or
> generation one?

Nah..  I wouldn't worry about this in your implement=
ation.  There are 
considerably more difficult problems to solve.  For exam=
ple, I'm 
finding that Ken's papers leave out quite a few implementation 
d=
etails, and that ultimately you'll have to look at his code to 
derive the =
entire algorithm.

NEAT is a wonderful invention - it's just not completely=
 documented.  
I'm working toward that documentation goal myself.

--Steve
